revisions.rev:
[[Image:Kent flag.svg|thumb|right|200px|White horse of Kent on the [[Flag of Kent]].]]
The '''White horse of Kent''', or the '''White Horse Rampant''', is a symbol of [[Kent]],<ref name=BBC7880889/> a county in [[South East England]].
The figure of the prancing (or [[Attitude_(heraldry)#Rampant|rampant]] in heraldry) [[white horse]] can also be referred to as '''Invicta''', which is the [[Invicta (motto)|motto of Kent]].<ref name=BBC7880889>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/kent/7880889.stm |title=Giant horse to become Â£2m artwork |date=10 February 2009<!-- 11:49 GMT -->|accessdate=10 February 2009 |publisher=[[BBC News]] |quote=A prancing white horse is the logo for the county council and has been the symbol of Kent for hundreds of years. However, a sculpture of the Invicta, supported by Kent County Council in response to Mr Wallinger's entry, was rejected by judges last year.}}</ref>
==Origin== The white [[horse]] of Kent is the old symbol for the [[Jutes|Jutish]] [[kingdom of Kent]], dating from the 6th - 8th century.<ref>[http://www.hampshireflag.co.uk/world-flags/allflags/gb-kent.html www.hampshireflag.co.uk] Coat of Arms</ref>
The white horse relates to the emblem of [[Horsa]], the brother of [[Hengest]], who defeated the King [[Vortigern]] near [[Aylesford]]. The first recorded reference to the white horse can be found in ''Restitution of Decayed Antiquities'' from [[1605]] by [[Richard Verstegan]]. The book shows an engraving of Hengist and Horsa landing in Kent in [[449]] under the banner of a rampant white horse. Indeed, continental origins of this emblem can be found from the coat of arms of [[Lower Saxony]], the Dutch region of [[Twente]], the [[House of Welf]] (who adapted it in the late 14th century; before then the Welf coat of arms was a golden lion on red ground) and the modern German State of [[North Rhine-Westphalia]]: the [[Saxon Steed]]. Some historians note that [[Jutes]] migrating to Kent through the continent may have been associated with the [[Rhineland]] south of the Saxons.
<gallery> File:Coat of arms of Lower Saxony.svg|[[Coat of arms of Lower Saxony|Coat of arms]] of [[Lower Saxony]], in Germany. File:Coat of arms of North Rhine-Westfalia.svg|[[Coat of arms of North Rhine-Westphalia|Coat of arms]] of [[North Rhine-Westphalia]], in Germany. File:Twenthe.svg|Flag of the region of [[Twente]], in The Netherlands. </gallery>
==Usage== The horse is a key part of the official [[coat of arms]] of the county, and appears on the coat of arms of many of the Boroughs of Kent<ref>[http://www.civicheraldry.co.uk/kent.html www.civicheraldry.co.uk] Kent Borough Council coats of arms</ref> and on the [[University of Kent#Coat of arms|University of Kent coat of arms]]. The horse is depicted on the [[Flag of Kent]] and forms part of the modern logos of [[Kent County Council]], the [[Kent Fire and Rescue Service]] and the [[Kent Police]].
The horse also features on the logos of many companies and sports teams in Kent. It was used on the former ''[[Invictaway]]'' London commuter coaches operated by [[Maidstone & District]].<ref>[http://nationalbusco.fotopic.net/p12901490.html Image of a black liveried Invictaway bus]</ref><ref>[http://flickr.com/photos/andytakersdad/1472885872/in/set-72157601795326096/ Image of a green liveried Invictaway bus]</ref> A large number of [[pubs]] in the county also feature ''White Horse'' in their name, although this also occurs around the [[United Kingdom]] and may not necessarily relate to the Kent horse.
<gallery> File:Arms-kent.jpg|Arms of [[Kent County Council]]. File:Kent Coat of Arms.jpg|Coat of arms of the [[University of Kent]]. File:Kent County Council logo.png|Logo of [[Kent County Council]]. File:Kent Fire & Rescue Service Logo.jpg|Logo of the [[Kent Fire and Rescue Service]]. File:Kent police.gif|Logo of the [[Kent Police]]. </gallery>
==See also== * [[Folkestone White Horse]], a hill figure in Kent. * [[White Horse Stone]], [[megaliths]] near [[Aylesford]], Kent. * [[The White Horse at Ebbsfleet]], alternate name for the planned [[Angel of the South]] sculpture in Ebbsfleet, Kent.
